I was contemplating the shape of a sphere recently and considered what makes up the shape of a sphere. It's seemingly infinite points made up of the same radius. To me,
a sphere represents chaos. A cube, on the other hand, is an example of order. Imagine a single point on a sphere. Now imagine that point travelling in a seemingly random directions, but maintaining the same radius. The speed, combined with the directional pattern, is how to determine the fingerprint of a particle, as all particles are made up of a spherical shape. So what if the answer to unlocking the secrets of time crystals is to look at the relationship between chaos and order, and that, combined with the signature spin of each particle, provides new ways to control and manipulate matter.

One thing I must point out, and perhaps my opinion on this is a result for my natural curiosity and sense of adventure, but by comparing a cube with a sphere, I think we can then turn the impossible into possible by utilizing our knowledge of order.

Take for example a shpere and a cube of the same dimensions. The sphere connects with the center point of a cube, on all 6 planes.

This creates new hedron shapes in each corner of the cube, of the absent space between the cube and sphere.

If you stack 8 cubes, each with their respective same sized spheres inside, the very center of the bigger cube is a star-like shape called a hyperbolic octahedron.

This is what I define as a true opposite of a sphere, even though there are other theories and definitions for the opposite of a sphere.

Perhaps having control over the 6 points, all pointed at the center, could provide a working mechanism for particle creation.

I am by no means an expert in any field so take anything I say with a huge grain of salt.

I'm not a seasoned science enthusiast by any means. I love to listen about cool things like this from time to time, or something to do with space or our world. This particular discovery seems to push the boundaries of what everyone understands to be possible, and for me, it speaks to the very heart and soul of what science is. It's not about discovering a set of perceived rules and seeing how everything adheres to them; it's about discovering what doesn't fit those rules, and coming to understand how and why. I've always wondered why there are so many scientists throughout history that have discredited ideas and theories because they didn't fit with the current rules of the time, only for these ideas and theories to be proven years later. True the proving usually happens after said scientists have already passed, but still. In my opinion, approaching science as something set in stone that can't possibly ever change is so limiting. It could ALWAYS change! We are discovering newer and weirder things every single day! Time crystals are just one of those things! If we approach science with the mindset of 'this is how it's done, these are the rules, that's impossible because of this rule' then we could miss out on huge discoveries, or be humiliated later when something previously discredited turns out to be real.
Basically I wish that the subject of science as approached by professionals was more open-minded and interested in pushing the limits of what we know by looking outside the box.

In our daily lives regular computers, only bit are processed and if we had, for example, an encrypted hard drive to crack because our lives depended on the data of that drive and we were trying a brute-force-attack on that encryption, we would have to wait for a very long time to de-crypt that drive.
However, when all things go as planned, the qubits in a quantum-computer would be able to have not only a 0 and a 1at any given time to process, but both of them at the same time, or in layman's-terms, the quantum-computer would de-crypt that hard drive's encryption in a few seconds at most.

FYI, neutrons don't have a 0 charge, they have a very slight negative charge, which is what keeps the protons and electrons separated. It's effect is extremely difficult to measure other than spin, which gives an atom polarity based on the placement of electrons around a nucleus at any instant. Since the e- charges don't regularly align, the forces between the particles produce a slightly polar charge with electrons taking different paths and reaching different orbital alignments close or far apart. The e- of a neutron produces a push, the proton overtakes this with a pull. Since we can only measure placements of electrons by energizing them and changing that position, most of our understanding is based on observations of a secondary nature. Most atoms have a neutral polarity in increments of 1s, but at particularly small slices of that second, the polarity changes.
The time crystal theory isn't just from 2012. In fact, something similar was imagined long before, describing a material whose nature forced it to generate an almost gravitic reversion style energy by very rapidly altering state and temperature, in such a manner that an extreme temperature was sustained for such a short period that the average temperature was slightly above room temperature. Disney put it into a movie called "The Absent Minded Professor", the title character of which was keen on using a radiation burst to energize the material in such a fashion that it could make his old model T fly. Later, Disney reitterated the film with Robbin Williams' genius behind the professor and a T-bird instead of a Model T.
Technically, water fits this description. It's state, dependent on its temperature and the pressure of the system in which it is contained, changes back and forth through time. It has 3 standard states, though not many have been too keen on discussion of hydro-plasma states.

Just in case anyone is wondering this is actually a joke. Quantum computer use zeros and ones to process yes and no. And further use those zeros and ones in specific sequences as catalogs to mark colors and numbers. 0000100011 may be the color magenta. where 010001010010010 may be the color green. The processing boards on the computer are filled with millions of nano processors that each have specifications linked to specific yes and no answers. And further your software has it's own unique address that lets other software on other computers identify it. So you connect to a piece of software on your computer to another persons computer that is acting like a server. It has to program running 24/7 like facebook. With its unique address you computer asks for. And establishes a connection. And they communicate using using the same zeros and ones in a program to understand each other. An example of this is Microsoft using ccc programming under specific principles of zeros and ones standing for specific instructions in the 0100101 sequences programmed into the software. And the software you are getting information from understands the ccc language. Thus, it knows what information you are asking for and how to give you the results.

so it isn't a problem at all for a computer to run programs in a sequence pattern. It actually how it functions at all. If it did not. You would never recieve anything other than scrambled information that wouldn't be readable.

Fun Fact about Quantum Spin! Even though electrons, "have spin," it's physically impossible for them to actually be spinning.

Let me explain.

"Spin" is also known as Angular Momentum, which describes how something is rotating and what axis its rotating around. Or in the case of an orbiting object, how fast it's revolving.
But we're talking electrons here, so we're talking about an object rotating around an axis.
Now we have no reason to believe that electrons aren't spherical, so let's picture an electrons like it's a planet rotating on its axis. Or, an electron could be a point-particle. We don't really know which. But, we do have a measurement of how large it could be, if it's not a point. Think of it as an upper limit on the electron's radius.

Now where does "physically impossible" come in. I'm getting there. We need the background first!

Now, the equations for a rotating sphere can tell us how fast any point on its surface is moving. A point at the equator is the easiest, since we only need the sphere's radius and how fast it's rotating … i.e. it's Angular Momentum. You can easily google how fast a point on Earth's equator is moving, so I'm not gonna put that here.

So, we've got:
 (1) Equation for taking 'sphere radius' and 'sphere Angular Momentum' that computes how fast the sphere's equator is moving;
 (2) Upper-limit on the Electron's radius;
 (3) Electron-spin, i.e. its Angular Momentum.
Combine those together, and you get — the equator of an electron is moving faster than the speed of light. Much faster. Much, much faster.

This is a computation that they throw at physics majors in sophomore-year Intro to Quantum-Mechanics: Electrons "have spin", but they can't actually be spinning.

So a "time crystal" is, well, just an oscillator:
The flipping random bits back and forth between states is what one expects to happen even in a common quartz crystal structure when acting as a tuning fork...
The surface imperfections may expand and contract back and forth in harmonics and yet will end up in relatively the same state on each cycle.
Relatively is due to the macro scale and the differing energy states on each cycle pulsing the crystal, whereas on a single atom scale, the states are closely coupled to their locals.
That is, if both are put into their steady state (at rest) then they will return to that steady state.
That's why this "quantum time crystal" doesn't break the laws of thermal dynamics. Otherwise the typical 32.768Khz crystal that helps keep track of relative time (relative to our path around the sun) would be impossible.
Thus I logically conclude that this is not a time crystal in the context of "4th dimension" but merely a quantum oscillator that flips the q-bits in inversion according to the wave phase angle it's riding, just like normal macro scale oscillators.

Seems to me calling these oscillators "crystals" is a stretch, because time isn't a dimension: it's not possible to identify two points on the "line of time" simultaneously (indeed, the very notion is incoherent). What's being measured is the only time-point that ever exists--now--versus an imaginary (typically, remembered ) time-point. Every time-point identified is always the same one--now--and thus time is a point, not a dimension. In other words, it has no measurable concrete extent, the "line of time" existing only abstractly. And if time isn't a dimension then these aren't crystals.

(I realize treating time as if it were a dimension makes relativity work, but that's not to say relativity is correct. Given that it erroneously conflates the concrete and abstract into one allegedly real thing, i.e., "space-time", it's probably not surprising that it's incompatible with QM, because this credulity-straining conceptual maneuver is a big hint there's something fundamentally wrong with the model.)

The second law of thermodynamics does not say that the universe goes to wars higher entropy/chaos.
It says that any system that can be approximated as closed has to either be at thermal equilibrium or move towards thermal equilibrium.
To move towards thermal equilibrium would mean to increase the entropy.
But the entropy can't move further than the thermal equilibrium.

But for a system to move towards thermal equilibrium there has to be a disturbance of the system, of external origin, to begin with.
The system has to be open.
A system can't magically just be in low entropy at any point if it is a truly closed system.
Meaning all truly closed systems have to be stable.

To say it simple...
If the entropy of a system is increasing then it had to decrease at some point.
Otherwise there would be no reason for the system to find stability

Yes, thermal equilibrium means that the system is as stable as it gets.
On earth we approximate thermal equilibrium.
But there is only one thermal equilibrium and that is the universe.

A system in thermal equilibrium doesn't have to be simple.
It will be as complicated as the forces of nature demands it.
Imagine it as the over all energy and the forces of nature fighting each other.
Thermal equilibrium is when the forces and the energy are in balance.
The energy can't spread out more evenly than this.
Since the forces binds the energy in place.

We live in an extremely complicated system that is in thermal equilibrium.
A true perpetual machine.
Big bang can't have happened as most cosmologists believe.
Either it appear static, or you will see the fluctuations.
When viewed in a small scale it appears to be unstable.
But at large the system is stable.
When you look at a piece of metall you do not see the chaotic nature of quantum physics.
The universe is quasiunstable.
But it has to be ultimately stable.
Otherwise we have to question science as a method.
That is how important thermodynamics is to science.

I am curious to see what this may have to do with multi qubit arrangements. It is only relatively recently that multi qubit systems have been able to reach high levels of accuracy thanks to a form of qubit cross referencing. Essentially what they do is run the results of a qubit against the results of another, and are able to detect with almost 99% accuracy whether or not the computation was accurate. This is very important for being able to scale up quantum computers. This ability to scale up in qubits while retaining accuracy is going to be extremely important leading into the future, and I wonder what effects time crystals seeming to have memory may have on this going forward.

Thoughts on the matter:
* We do, technically, have perpetual motion in physics if we think about a perfect cyclical orbit. Energy stays the same, but motion happens.
* By definition of "periodic in time", every crystal is a time crystal: its state is still and unchanging throughout
* Using spin honestly sounds like cheating here, as it is hard to consider a "state of matter" - no bonds are altered, no atoms are realigned.

"SPIN": Consider the following: The Earth spins. If we look down on the Earth from the North pole, the Earth would be spinning counter clockwise. But just by changing our perspective, with the same spinning Earth, looking 'down' on the Earth from the South pole, the Earth would be spinning clockwise.

Electrons ONLY spin one way, BUT it is our perspective that says whether they are spinning clockwise or counter clockwise.

Time is weird. Most people think they understand it, but the truth is that no one does. I've had a problem with the idea of time as the "fourth dimension" for decades. If time is a dimension in a 4 dimensional construct, it is different to the 3 spatial dimensions because it is not orthogonal to them. This is because, while you can move through time without moving through space (by being perfectly stationary with respect to the universe - and you can't do this on the earth's surface), and you can move through any of the 3 spatial dimensions without moving through the others, you can't move through space in any of the 3 dimensions without moving through time.

In super layman's terms: In a regular computer, a bit can only be either 0 or 1. (Off or on if you prefer.)
In a quantum computer, a qubit can either be 0 or 1. Or both. (In a superposition.)

To imagine what that can get you, take encryption. If you have 256 bit encryption, a regular computer would take literally millions of years to break that, because it has to calculate each of the possibilities (of 2 to the 256th power) separately. It will do so at trillions of possibilities per second, but it's still an absurd number it has to do.
A 256 bit quantum computer will theoretically crack that instantaneously, because it can calculate every single possible combination instantaneously.

That said, a quantum computer is not inherently more powerful than a regular computer, it's just good at doing completely different things.

Easy and extremely basic explanation of a quantum computer:
Normal computer uses bits which can be a 1 or a 0. This is a measurement that if a transistor can pass an electron or cannot (NPN gates).
A quantum computer uses qubits, which can be 1, 0, 1+0. This means that it can be on, off, or in both states at the same time.

I mean, that is overly simplistic, but it is the basic foundation/theory in how they use quantum properties of electrons instead of electron macro-effects.

Things oscillating in one or more of our 3D dimensions are doing so while still tracking along the 4D temporal axis.... going along a 3D axis from a starting point to the opposing point and back to the starting point. Thus, if something were oscillating in TIME, it would be going back and forth THROUGH TIME, along the temporal axis, from the present to the past and the present and the past, etc. Being as WE continue to MOVE along the time axis, we would be leaving it behind in time.... we'd be moving away in time from the oscillatory event.

What appears to be getting described here is an energetic oscillation that is independent of requiring energy input. However, think of a proton, existing for trillions of years of its own accord, requiring no further input of energy to keep doing what it does naturally. Its spin is a form of oscillation requiring no further energy input.

And all matter is travelling along with us along the 4D axis; and we can easily perceive that none of it is "backing up" through time, as it would vanish from view into the past.
BUT!! Perhaps that's what particles in the quantum foam are doing... perhaps those particles that appear to disappear and others mysteriously appear (in a quantum vacuum) are the REAL "time travelling particles"... backing away from our moving perspective point in time and then rapidly sliding forward again INTO it, and perhaps even continuing a short distance into the future (where they would again appear to "vanish" from our temporal frame) and then come sliding back towards us.

At a laymen level a "qbit" is just some "thing" that can have more than 2 states (which is what binary/"normal" computers use). You could define a quantum computer if it used "bits" that had at least 3 states - yes/no/maybe - but the problem with the quantum world is once you measure it, it is basically a binary outcome, you need more than 2 measurable states per "bit" (and the space of that "bit" needs to compete with the ludicrous level we already have with binary today). Also quantum computers have different strengths (and weaknesses) to binary ones - surfing the net and basic math, spreadsheets and documents is way up a binary/digital computers alley whereas passwords and keys become useless with quantum computers.

I love this vid not only because it’s super interesting but also because I’m a physics undergrad who wants to go into quantum computing after grad school and whenever I try to explain what a qubit/quantum computer is to someone who doesn’t know much physics, I give the same explanation as physics girl did almost word for word- I got a both a great vid to watch and validation that I’m explaining my fave topic well :)

Some more on what makes quantum computers different:

In your regular computer, each but is either a 1, or a 0, on, or off. Technically, since we define 1 and 0 as falling within a range of voltages in a circuit, the voltage can be a wide range of values, but we don't use it that way. We then use each bit to perform calculations by connecting them up to a circuit which can perform that calculation for each bit of data individually.

By contrast, quantum computers generally use qbits which are entangled together in a special way. By entangling them, you end up multiplying the number of values you can encode in a single bit. Beyond that, you also get the ability to do calculations where you "try every possible combination at the same time" and whatever you get out should be something close to the right result. This lets you try to solve problems that would require a classical computer to calculate each possible solution and test them 1 at a time. Once you have too many solutions, trying each one, 1 by 1, becomes impossible, since it's possible to have many more solutions than you could possibly calculate in the lifespan of the universe. But quantum computers can essentially "try every solution at once" and just somehow get the answer (ignoring the difficulty of quantum error correction).

I try to explain computers vs quantum computers in terms of a basic switch. A common power switch has two positions, on and off. This open or closed circuit is often depicted with an "I" for on, or a "O" for off. Notice that the I and O on that switch are also "1" and "0". The term bit is just a single switch on a chip, on or off. This is the basis of standard computational code. Quantum computers use both 1 and 0 simultaneously within the qbit. All of the switches are both off and on simultaneously, but without a short circuit, until you look for the outcome. A qbit is Schrodinger's cat.

Richard Feynman's "Lectures on Physics" are super famous.  BUT, Feynman ALSO did lectures on computer science!  In them, he determined that computation can be performed at the quantum scale with zero energy being used.  It required infinite time, though, if I remember right.  It had to do with setting up a quantum system so that your solution was the ground state of all quantum particles involved, and they would eventually fall to that state without any energy being input, you just couldn't predict how long that would take.  His lectures on the topic were all about the fundamentals of computing based on physics.  They're available as a book, but I never see anyone talking about it.  I've read it and IMO, he brings as much genius to computer science as physics.  You just have to remember... computer scientists study computers the way astrophysicists study telescopes.

Here is a simple, hopefully better explanation of what a quantum computer can do: Normal computers can have a bit that is either turned on or off, which would be represented as a  0 or 1. So for example, to store the number 2 you would have to have 2 bits, as 0 is 0 in binary. 1 is 1 but 2 is 1 and a 0. Essentially, how many states a normal computer can be in is 2 to the power of how many bits there are. So, 10 bits is 2^10. However, a qubit in a quantum computer, can be in 3 different positions instead of 2. To leave out spin, then let's just represent it as 1 and 0. A qubit can be 1, 0 but also 1 and 0 at the same time, which is called superposition. It would be like if you had a coin that could land on both heads and tails at the same time! This means that fewer qubits can represent more states, as it is 3 to the power of qubits. So, 10 bits could be in 2^10 = 1024 states while 10 qubits could be in 3^10 = 59049 states. Therefore, with quantum computers, we can work with way bigger numbers!

I really dislike describing entropy as chaos. I feel it so misleading. Especially since a lot of what we describe as ordered would not exist without entropy. It is a matter of perspective. Is a glass where one side is cold and one is hot, more ordered than compared to a class with perfectly uniformed heat distribution? What if you had a glass with hot and cold spot compared to one with uniformed heat distribution? You can make something that seem messy and set it up in a way that it would evolve towards a less messy, uniformed state. So while the glass that is half hot and half cold may seem ordered. It no more order in that sense then one with random distribution of blobs of heat and cold. You in the end are forced to define order and chaos based on what you want entropy to be which make it moot and sometimes very counterintuitive. (Such as claiming the universe was in a more ordered state just after the big bang than Earth is today, since the entropy is higher now.)

I cant understand the word ... " Intergermolmol..?! "
And btw, the term " FREQUENCY " is the best term to use. " LENGTH " is less precise.
To describe waves, any types of waves, we should use the terms ( frequency and amplitude ) .
If a wave is an " up-down / positive-negative " movement, then, AMPLITUDE is " how high and Low the wave reaches", and the FREQUENCY is " how many times does it go from High to Low in 1 second "
High amplitude low frequency waves are strong yet cant go far and remain strong.
Low amplitude low frequency are almost useless. Weak and short distance.
High amplitude high frequency go far and remain strong longer.
Low amplitude high frequency go far even though they are "weak".
Wave Length is a distance in meters between 2 peaks of a wave and based on what we know about the speed of light...
Anyway, it's easier to understand and comprehend with FREQUENCY and AMPLITUDE.

How can particle with spin pointing upwards "flip" and be pointing downwards without making continuous rotation from 0 to 180? It's more like that the particle will be removed from space with spin pointing upwards and replaced with the same particle already rotated by 180 with spin pointing downwards. In our physics model, you have to rotate the particle from 0 to 1, 2, 3, 4, 5...degrees continuously to achieve target 180. You can't just have 0 and then 180 right away. In my mind,  it is either that the particle spin orientation happens so fast that we don't have a device to measure it yet so to us it appears 0 and 180 only, or the particle is entangled with another particle in quantum space and time that has opposite spin direction and they just exchange each other's positions at once. I really didn't like the explanation of what a quantum computer is. I mean - its not wrong, its just doesn't explain whyb it's a good idea.

I would try to explain it this way: a regular (binary) computer calculates by computing a set of input bits into a solution through a set of rules that calculate some simple math then check the result and according to that make additional calculations and so on and so forth - like a human working at solving an equation - and that takes time to process each step linearly. In a quantum computer, on the other hand, you can encode your rules as a set of entanglements between the quantum states of the input qubits and when you observe the actual value of the qubit, the wave function collapse causes the output qubits to immediately resolve to the solution in almost no time (the speed of light not withstanding), so it is much much faster, theoretically making computations that can take many years on an advanced binary computer, solvable instantaneously.

The biggest defining feature of a quantum computer isn't the way the states of the individual qubits work. It's the fact that the different quibits can be entangled so the state of the computer as a whole can be sort of 'confined' to a solution by manipulating the qubits very carefully so as to entangle them in just the right way, and not disturb the entangled state once you've created it.
